facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 53 of 1964 before the Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 53 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 9, 1963 of the Bombay High Court  Nag

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and order dated August 9, 1963 of Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench in Criminal Revision Application No. 107 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 9, 1963 of the Bombay High Court  Nagpur Bench  in Criminal Revision Application No. 107 of 1963.

facts.text: Ratan Lal is the appellant and proprietor of Anil Medical Stores at Wani, District Yeotmal, Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: Ratan Lal-appellant in this appeal-is the pro- prietor of a business in drugs styled Anil Medical Stores at Wani, District Yeotmal in the State of Maharashtra.

facts.text: On September 14, 1960, Station House Officer Wani raided the appellant's shop and seized 12 bottles of Mahadrakshasava manufactured by Brahma Aushadhalaya Nagpur and 88 bottles of Dashmoolarishta manufactured by Vedic Pharmaceutical Works Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: On September 14, 1960 the Station House Officer, Wani, raided the shop of the appellant and seized 12 bottles of an Ayurvedic preparation called Mahadrakshasva manufactured by the Brahma Aushadhalaya, Nagpur and 88 bottles of Dashmoolarishta manufactured by the Vedic Pharmaceutical Works, Nagpur.

facts.text: Appellant convicted by Magistrate First Class Kalapur under s.66(1)(b) Bombay Prohibition Act 1949, sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for three months and fine Rs.500.

anchor.surface_text: At a trial held before the Magistrate, First Class, Kalapur, the appellant was companyvicted of the offence punishable under s. 66 1  b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act 25 of 1949, and was sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for three months and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-

facts.text: Conviction confirmed in appeal by Court of Session Yeotmal.

anchor.surface_text: The order was companyfirmed in appeal by the Court of Session, Yeotmal.

facts.text: Bombay High Court confirmed conviction but modified sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Bombay companyfirmed the companyviction, but modified the sentence.

facts.text: Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta are Ayurvedic medicinal preparations containing alcohol, manufactured under licences under Medicinal and Toilet Preparations Excise Duties Act 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The following are the material facts found by the trial Court and companyfirmed by the Court of Appeal and the High Court. Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta are Ayurvedic medicinal preparations companytaining alcohol, manufactured under licences granted under the Medicinal and Toilet Preparations  Excise Duties  Act 16 of 1955.

facts.text: Mahadrakshasava seized contained 52.3% alcohol v/v and Dashmoolarishta 54.5% alcohol v/v.

anchor.surface_text: Mahadrakshasava attached from the shop of the appellant companytained 52.3 alcohol v v and Dashmoolarishta companytained 54.5 alcohol v v.

facts.text: Preparations manufactured by process of distillation.

anchor.surface_text: there was on the record clear evidence that the offending preparations were manufactured by a process of distillation and were number preparations in which alcohol was generated by fermentation.

facts.text: Appellant purchased preparations from Sharda Medical Stores Nagpur, supplied by manufacturers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had purchased these preparations from a drug store in Nagpur called the Sharda Medical Stores who in their turn were supplied by the manufacturers the Brahma Aushadhalaya, Nagpur and the Vedic Pharmaceutical Works, Nagpur.

facts.text: Lower courts held preparations were fermented with alcohol exceeding 12% by volume, not complying with s.59A.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held that the offending articles were Ayurvedic preparations in which alcohol was generated by a process of fermentation and as alcohol exceeded 12 per cent by volume, the preparations did number companyrespond with the limitations prescribed by S. 59A

facts.text: Evidence showed preparations are distilled Ayurvedic products, conceded by State before Sessions and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Palnitkar, Sub-Inspector of Prohibition Excise, said that Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta are distilled Ayurvedic products. Apparently it was companyceded on behalf of the State before the Court of session that the two preparation were Ayurvedic medicinal preparations which companytained alcohol produced by distillation

facts.text: Preparations manufactured within Maharashtra by licensed manufacturers under 1955 Act, issued from bonded warehouse.

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that these preparation were manufactured within the State of Maharashtra by manufacturers licensed under the Medicinal and Toilet Preparations  Excise Duties  Act 16 of 1955 and were issued from a bonded warehouse.

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra issued declaration on October 4, 1960 declaring Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta fit for use as intoxicating liquor after consulting Board of Experts.

anchor.surface_text: After companysulting the Board of Ex- perts the Government of Maharashtra issued a declaration on October 4, 1960, declaring that both the preparations Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta were medicines fit for use as intoxicating liquor.

facts.text: Police report filed on June 2, 1962 in Magistrate First Class court charging appellant under s.66(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter a police report was filed in the Court of the Magistrate, First Class, on June 2, 1962 charging the appellant with the offence under s. 66 1  b  of the Bombay Prohibition Act.

facts.text: Raid and seizure occurred on September 14, 1960, before the October 4, 1960 declaration.

anchor.surface_text: But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor.

facts.text: Bombay Prohibition Act amended by Act 22 of 1960 brought into force on April 20, 1960, incorporating s.6A(7).

anchor.surface_text: By Act 22 of 1960, which was brought into force on April 20, 1960, the Bombay Legislature amended, inter alia, sub-s.  6  of S. 6A, and incorporated sub-s.  7  therein.

facts.text: Appellant contended possession not contravention as medicinal preparations unfit for intoxicating use under s.24A.

anchor.surface_text: His case was that possession of the preparations by him was number in companytravention of the Act, because the preparations were medicinal preparations companytaining alcohol which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor within the meaning of s. 24A of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held lower courts misconceived evidence on manufacturing process.

anchor.surface_text: But it appears that in so holding, the Courts misconceived the evidence.

anchor.surface_text: and it is number the case of the appellant that he was protected by a licence, permit, pass or authorization.

holdings.text: The preparations containing alcohol were medicinal preparations unfit for use as intoxicating liquor within s.24A as they complied with s.59A and were deemed unfit under s.6A(7) at the time of offence.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined in this appeal is whether the preparations containing alcohol in respect of which the appellant is convicted were medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preparations medicinal per Ayurvedic system; distilled not fermented; no evidence of excess alcohol beyond necessary; licensed under 1955 Act; deemed unfit under s.6A(7) until state determination post-offence.

holdings.text: The preparations were not manufactured by fermentation generating alcohol exceeding 12% but by distillation.

anchor.surface_text: But it appears that in so holding, the Courts misconceived the evidence. Articles containing alcohol may be prepared by a process of fermentation which generates alcohol or by a process of distillation or by addition of free alcohol. The manufacturing processes which result in distillation of alcohol and generation of alcohol by fermentation are distinct, and there was on the record clear evidence that the offending preparations were manufactured by a process of distillation and were not preparations in which alcohol was generated by fermentation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts misconstrued evidence; witness Palnitkar stated distilled; state conceded before sessions and high court; distinct processes.

holdings.text: No evidence that preparations contained alcohol exceeding quantity necessary under first part of s.59A; comply as licensed under 1955 Act from bonded warehouse.

anchor.surface_text: Palnitkar, Sub-Inspector of Prohibition Excise, said that Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta are distilled Ayurvedic products. Apparently it was conceded on behalf of the State before the Court of session that the two preparation were Ayurvedic medicinal preparations which contained alcohol produced by distillation, and before the High Court also the case was argued on that footing. If the bottles of Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta attached from the shop of the appellant contained alcohol produced by distillation, the proviso to S. 59A will have no application. There is no evidence on the record to prove that the two preparations contained alcohol in excess of the quantity permissible under the first paragraph of S. 59A. It must be remembered that these preparation were manufactured within the State of Maharashtra by manufacturers licensed under the Medicinal and Toilet Preparations Excise Duties Act 16 of 1955 and were issued from a bonded warehouse.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso inapplicable to distillation; no proof of excess; licensing infers compliance.

holdings.text: Medicinal preparation complying with s.59A is not fit for intoxicating use absent s.6A determination; s.6A prescribes special evidence rules.

anchor.surface_text: But it was urged for the State that a medicinal preparation which corresponds with the description and limitations under s. 59A may still be a preparation which is fit to be used as intoxicating liquor. ... But the Legislature has by s. 6A prescribed special rules of evidence in adjudging whether an article is unfit for use as intoxicating liquor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature overrode general evidence by s.6A post-Balsara; deeming and presumption rules exclusive.

holdings.text: Under amended s.6A(7), until State Government determines article fit after Board advice, deemed unfit for intoxicating use.

anchor.surface_text: By Act 22 of 1960, which was brought into force on April 20, 1960, the Bombay Legislature amended, inter alia, sub-s. (6) of S. 6A, and incorporated sub-s. (7) therein... Until the State Government has determined as aforesaid any article mentioned in subsection (1) to be fit for use as intoxicating liquor, every such article shall be deemed to be unfit for such use.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment alters scheme; creates deeming fiction operative until state acts on Board advice.

holdings.text: State declaration post-offence has no retrospective operation; cannot render prior innocent possession criminal.

anchor.surface_text: But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, could not have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent could not, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deeming continues till determination; post-facto declaration non-retroactive per no_retrospectivity principle.

holdings.text: Amended s.6A prescribes exclusive mode of proof for State that article fit: Board advice and state determination; presumption rebuttable thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: Under the amended S. 6A there is only one mode of proof by the State that an article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor, and that is by obtaining the advice of the Board of Experts and recording its determination, that the article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-amendment allowed aliunde proof (Narandas); s.6A(7) deeming and s.6A(6) presumption now exclusive scheme.

precedents.citation: The State of Bombay number Gujarat v. Narandas Mangilal Agarwal Another 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court held in The State of Bombay  number Gujarat  v. Narandas Mangilal Agarwal Another 1  that it was number obligatory upon the State to companysult the Board of Experts companystituted under s. 6A before the State companyld establish in a prosecution for an offence under S. 66 1   b  that a medicinal preparation was unfit for use as intoxicating liquor.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay (now Gujarat) v. Narandas Mangilal Agarwal & Another
precedents.cited_proposition: not obligatory upon the State to consult the Board of Experts under s. 6A before establishing in prosecution that medicinal preparation was fit for use as intoxicating liquor; prosecution need not rely on s.6A; no condition precedent
precedents.cited_holding: consultation with Board of Experts under s.6A not obligatory or condition precedent for prosecution

precedents.citation: D. K. Merchant, v. The State of Bombay 2

anchor.surface_text: In so holding, this Court disagreed with the view expressed by the Bombay High Court in D. K. Merchant, v. The State of Bombay 2  wherein the High Court had held that the prosecution for offence under ss. 65 and 66 companyld number be maintained unless the State Government was satisfied after companysulting the Board of Experts under S. 6A that the article was fit to be used as intoxicating liquor.

precedents.case_name: D. K. Merchant v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: prosecution for offences under ss. 65 and 66 could not be maintained unless State Government satisfied after consulting Board of Experts under s.6A that article fit for use as intoxicating liquor

anchor.surface_text: The offence in Narandas Mangilals case 1  was companymitted in July 1955 and on the terms of sub-s.  6  as it then stood it was open to the State in a prosecution for infringement of a prohibition companytained in ss. 12 and 13 to rely upon the presumption under S. 6A or to establish that the medicinal preparation was fit for use as intoxicating liquor aliunde.

precedents.case_name: Narandas Mangilal Agarwal & Another v. State of Bombay (now Gujarat)
precedents.cited_proposition: offence committed in July 1955; under then sub-s.(6) State could rely on presumption under s.6A or prove aliunde that preparation fit for intoxicating use

anchor.surface_text: It is unfortunate that the High Court lost sight of the change in the scheme of S. 6A and followed the judgment of this Court in Narandas Mangilals case 1 .

precedents.case_name: Narandas Mangilal Agarwal & Another v. State of Bombay (now Gujarat)
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court followed it but overlooked amendment changing the scheme

anchor.surface_text: In Narandas Mangilals case at all material times when the question fell to be companysidered, the Court had to decide whether sub-s.  6  of S. 6A, as it then stood. prescribed the only method of proof whether an offending medicinal preparation was unfit for use as intoxicating liquor, and this Court on the phraseology used by the Legislature came to the companyclusion that it was number the only method of proof.

precedents.case_name: Narandas Mangilal Agarwal & Another v. State of Bombay (now Gujarat)
precedents.cited_proposition: sub-s.(6) of s.6A as then stood did not prescribe the only method of proof that preparation unfit for intoxicating use

anchor.surface_text: But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

outcome.relief_summary: Conviction set aside as possession of the preparations was not an offence at the time of attachment since they were deemed unfit for use as intoxicating liquor under s.6A; subsequent declaration has no retrospective effect

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined in this appeal is whether the preparations containing alcohol in respect of which the appellant is convicted were medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor.

But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 on distillation not fermentation exceeding 12% addresses issue i2

anchor.surface_text: But it appears that in so holding, the Courts misconceived the evidence. Articles containing alcohol may be prepared by a process of fermentation which generates alcohol or by a process of distillation or by addition of free alcohol. The manufacturing processes which result in distillation of alcohol and generation of alcohol by fermentation are distinct, and there was on the record clear evidence that the offending preparations were manufactured by a process of distillation and were not preparations in which alcohol was generated by fermentation.

But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

edges.explanation: h3 no evidence of excess addresses i3 on excess quantity

anchor.surface_text: Palnitkar, Sub-Inspector of Prohibition Excise, said that Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta are distilled Ayurvedic products. Apparently it was conceded on behalf of the State before the Court of session that the two preparation were Ayurvedic medicinal preparations which contained alcohol produced by distillation, and before the High Court also the case was argued on that footing. If the bottles of Mahadrakshasava and Dashmoolarishta attached from the shop of the appellant contained alcohol produced by distillation, the proviso to S. 59A will have no application. There is no evidence on the record to prove that the two preparations contained alcohol in excess of the quantity permissible under the first paragraph of S. 59A. It must be remembered that these preparation were manufactured within the State of Maharashtra by manufacturers licensed under the Medicinal and Toilet Preparations Excise Duties Act 16 of 1955 and were issued from a bonded warehouse.

But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.

anchor.surface_text: By Act 22 of 1960, which was brought into force on April 20, 1960, the Bombay Legislature amended, inter alia, sub-s. (6) of S. 6A, and incorporated sub-s. (7) therein... Until the State Government has determined as aforesaid any article mentioned in subsection (1) to be fit for use as intoxicating liquor, every such article shall be deemed to be unfit for such use.

But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. anchor.surface_text: Under the amended S. 6A there is only one mode of proof by the State that an article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor, and that is by obtaining the advice of the Board of Experts and recording its determination, that the article is fit for use as intoxicating liquor.

But on the date on which the medicinal preparations were attached, the statute had provided that they shall be deemed for the purpose of the Act as articles unfit for use as intoxicating liquor. Possession of the medicinal preparations which were unfit for use as intoxicating liquor was, at the date when they were attached, number an offence. A subsequent declaration by the State that they were fit for use as intoxicating liquor, companyld number have any retrospective operation, and possession which was innocent companyld number, by subsequent act of the State, be declared as offending the statute.
